title: Hollywood writers still going strong, a month after strike began
description: Members of the Writers Guild of America continue to strike against the major Hollywood studios, pushing for higher pay, more residuals and regulations on AI, among other things.

title: Watch: President Biden will address the deal with Congress to avert debt default
description: President Biden will give a rare Oval Office address about the deal with Congress to avert default on the debt. The event is set to begin at 7 p.m. ET.

title: YouTube will no longer take down false claims about U.S. elections
description: The Google-owned video platform's reversal comes as former President Donald Trump continues to baselessly claim the 2020 election was stolen

title: At least 50 people are killed, hundreds trapped in India passenger train derailment
description: Two passenger trains derailed in eastern India, killing at least 50 people and trapping hundreds of others inside more than a dozen damaged rail cars.

title: South Korean pop culture is a hit worldwide. Now, video games are next
description: From the country that brought you your favorite boy band, drama series, fermented food, and more.

title: Mary Trump, E. Jean Carroll and Jennifer Taub launch romance novel on Substack
description: Love works in mysterious ways. The unlikely trio has teamed up on a story called The Italian Lesson. "An American woman goes to a hill town in Tuscany, opens a café, meets this hunk," Trump says.

title: A lullaby really can work magic. Science tells us why and how
description: Sometimes the right lullaby sends my kids off to dreamland so fast it makes me feel like I have a parenting superpower. Turns out the wonder of lullabies is confirmed by scientific research.

title: Congress created changes to food assistance. Here's what they mean
description: In an effort to avoid defaulting on the nation's loans, lawmakers created updates to SNAP, the nation's largest food assistance safety net. There are new work requirements as well as exemptions.

title: Pence won't be charged in DOJ classified documents investigation
description: Two sources confirm the Justice Department sent a letter to former Vice President Mike Pence saying the investigation would close without any finding of criminal wrongdoing.

title: A driver's car soared 120 feet after vaulting off of a tow truck's ramp in Georgia
description: The scary spectacle was captured on video by the body camera of a sheriff's deputy who was helping with another crash on the highway.

title: Tune in for a livestream from Mars — a rare, almost real-time look into space
description: On Friday 12 p.m. ET, spectators will have a chance to see the most current images of Mars possible, from the surface of the planet to Earth in 3 to 22 minutes, courtesy of the European Space Agency,

title: Senate passes GOP-led resolution to block Biden's student loan relief plan
description: With President Biden pledging a veto, the resolution amounts to a mostly symbolic show of congressional disapproval on a plan to cancel up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt.

title: The U.S. added 339,000 jobs in May. It's a stunningly strong number
description: Employers added a whopping 339,000 jobs in May, far above expectations, according to a report from the Labor Department on Friday. The unemployment rate rose to 3.7%, from 3.4% in April.

title: Electrical pulses that synchronize the sleeping brain appear to boost memory
description: Scientists have shown that deep brain stimulation during sleep can help people retain new information. The approach could help people with memory problems related to disorders like Alzheimer's.

title: U.S.-China divide looms as Asia security summit begins in Singapore
description: The summit has been overshadowed by China's refusal to let its defense minister meet with U.S. Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin at the forum.

title: Edith Kanaka'ole is the first Hawaiian woman to grace a U.S. quarter
description: "Aunty Edith," as she was known, helped revive the Hawaiian language, hula and chant.

title: When she won the first national spelling bee, Marie C. Bolden dealt a blow to racism
description: Her victory made national news, upending stereotypes about race less than 50 years after the end of slavery. It also sparked racist fury.

title: Don't default on the NPR news quiz! See if you can secure all the right answers
description: So much debt ceiling drama! Not to mention actual drama from the Succession series finale, and the ongoing sagas around a beluga whale and baby bison. How well were you paying attention?

title: Want Johnny Carson's desk? A trove of TV memorabilia is up for auction
description: Hollywood memorabilia collector James Comisar is relinquishing a trove of items — from scripts to costumes and even fake mustaches — that have taken decades to amass.

title: 60 years since 'The Children's Crusade' changed Birmingham and the nation
description: The Birmingham movement in 1963 was a turning point when children joined the struggle for equal rights. The brutal response from white segregationists galvanized support for the Civil Rights Act.

title: Poll: Americans say teachers are underpaid, about half of Republicans oppose book bans
description: Are parents, teachers and the public feeling as divided as the headlines make it seem? A pair of new NPR/Ipsos polls reveals division, to be sure, but also surprising consensus.

title: And the winning word is: A 14-year-old from Florida wins the National Spelling Bee
description: Dev Shah won by correctly spelling "psammophile," a noun that is used to describe animals and plants that prefer to live in sandy soil environments

title: Boeing finds new problems with Starliner space capsule and delays first crewed launch
description: Boeing was set to launch its first astronauts into space next month. But engineers found flammable tape and problems with the capsule's parachutes. The Starliner program has been plagued by delays.
